title: When substitutions go wrong: The most dramatic reactions after Granit Xhaka's X-rated strop
text:

For all the goals, VAR drama and humiliating thrashings this weekend's Premier League football brought us, the abiding image will probably be that of poor old Granit Xhaka.

The Arsenal midfielder was furious when fans cheered his substitution, and reacted with all the grace and maturity of a toddler who has just dropped an ice cream.

While trudging off the field, the Swiss international first waved his arms at supporters, then cupped his ear, and just to make sure the damage was well and truly done, unceremoniously told them in no uncertain terms to "f*** off."

His shirt was then ripped off, the captain's armband thrown away and he stormed straight down the tunnel.

(Image: Reuters)

Fans have been calling for him to be binned off by the club as a result - and manager Unai Emery claims that he was in the wrong for reacting in the way that he did.

It was certainly an intriguing spectacle for all us neutrals, but it is not the first time a substitute (or lack of in one case) has caused headlines.

Here's a look back at other infamous examples of substitutions gone wrong...

1) Hossam Ghaly (Tottenham v Blackburn, 2007)

(Image: Getty Images)

Up until that fateful day in May 2007, Egyptian midfielder Hossam Ghaly's Tottenham career was going ok.

He had put in some decent performances in the middle of the park and endeared himself to the Spurs faithful by scoring against rivals Chelsea in an FA Cup tie.

He burned bridges with them forever, however, when he reacted to being taken off in a game against Blackburn by ripping off his shirt and flinging it to the ground, a sign of disrespect which those at White Hart Lane were unable to forgive him for.

He was never to play for the club again, and was eventually sent on an unsuccessful loan to Derby before returning to his native Egypt.

2) Sergio Aguero (Man City v Tottenham, 2019)

(Image: Getty Images)

When Manchester City's all-time top goalscorer was replaced by Gabriel Jesus after 66 minutes there didn't appear to be any problems, with Aguero running off the pitch without any drama.

His notoriously intense manager Pep Guardiola, however, took issue with the Argentinean not leaving the field at the nearest exit, and the two appeared to have a bizarre touchline bust-up, which was split up by assistant manager Mikel Arteta after a few uncomfortable moments for everyone on the City bench.

The two kissed and made up when Jesus scored what they thought was a last-minute winner- only for the goal to be ruled out by VAR. It's a cruel world.

3) Arjen Robben (Monchengladbach v Bayern, 2017)

(Image: Getty Images)

When your reaction is so over-the-top that it leaves your teammates in fits of laughter, you know you may have gone a touch too far.

With Bayern 1-0 up away at Monchengladbach with five minutes to go, it seemed a fairly sensible decision to replace winger Arjen Robben with the more defensive minded Renato Sanches.

The Dutchman clearly didn't feel this way, however, and dismissively slapped manager Carlo Ancelotti's hand before slumping onto the bench in a real strop.

His teammates on the bench, including Xabi Alonso and Franck Ribery, were hardly sympathetic, and broke out in fits of laughter at Robben's petulant reaction. Always good to know your friends have got your back.

4) Cristiano Ronaldo (Man Utd v Man City, 2009)

It takes a brave man to kick off with Sir Alex Ferguson, but a young Cristiano Ronaldo did just that when he was withdrawn from the Manchester derby during a 2-0 win in 2009.

The Portuguese superstar was replaced by Paul Scholes after 58 minutes and was so flabbergasted by the decision that he slapped a drink out of a United coach's hand and appeared to almost be crying on the bench.

Ferguson played down the reaction after the game, but whether he was so cool with the player behind closed doors is another story.

5) The one that didn't happen: Kepa (Chelsea v Man City, 2019)

(Image: Getty Images)

Ok, it's debatable whether this one counts seeing as the substitution was never actually completed, but in terms of drama there is probably nothing that tops those five minutes of madness from last season's Carabao Cup final.

With Chelsea and City just a minute away from a penalty shootout, Blues boss Maurizio Sarri decided to make his final change and replace Kepa with spot-kick specialist Willy Caballero. There was just one problem: Kepa wasn't having any of it.

After a bizarre shouting match between the Spanish goalkeeper and the Italian coach, Sarri admitted defeat by flinging down a bottle and storming off towards the tunnel, and for a split second it looked like he would disappear forever.

In the end, however, he thought better of it, but probably wishes he'd never turned around as he only saw his side lose on penalties.

It was the beginning of the end for Sarri at Chelsea, but for the neutral it was one of the most extraordinary scenes ever witnessed on a football pitch.
description: Granit Xhaka's meltdown against Crystal Palace was not the first time we have seen players lose their tempers
